input.project_name: UPM-2772882 - 3600 Steeles Ave East Markham - 5 year Load bank testing
input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):billing completed by Sebastian Vandervort (2):work order closed by Sebastian Vandervort (3):work planning by Sebastian Vandervort (4):offer approved by Sebastian Vandervort (5):offer submitted by Sebastian Vandervort

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem: Load bank testing to be performed on the three generator Units for DC. Units tested are CAT 3516C #1, CAT 3516C #2 and CAT 3516C #3
scope_of_work.scope: 85% Load will be applied to al three generators for a period of 2 hours
scope_of_work.justification:
Load bank testing is an integral part of any facility that relies on generators. Testing these power producers before they're needed ensures they will function as expected without problems. By conducting load bank testing, you can avoid costly downtime caused by a faulty generator.
The load bank testing procedure helps your generator's operation in a few ways:

Exercises the generator: The process exercises the generator to keep it in full functioning condition. By getting regular use, the generator's parts are more likely to move and function as needed.
Prevents wet stacking: A load bank test prevents wet stacking, which can happen when diesel-powered generators don't have regular use and soot builds in the system. A load bank test runs fuels through the generator, helping burn off the diesel inside the engine.
Verifies generator ability: The load bank test verifies that the generator will be able to create various levels of power to support necessary electrical equipment during an outage.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: Without adequate load testing, the facility wont be able to validate the correct operational performance of the back-up system during load

The problem statement indicates: Load bank testing to be performed on the three generator Units for DC. Units tested are CAT 3516C #1, CAT 3516C #2 and CAT 3516C #3. The defined scope of work includes: 85% Load will be applied to al three generators for a period of 2 hours. The justification provided is: Load bank testing is an integral part of any facility that relies on generators. Testing these power producers before they're needed ensures they will function as expected without problems. By conducting load bank testing, you can avoid costly downtime caused by a faulty generator.
The load bank testing procedure helps your generator's operation in a few ways:

Exercises the generator: The process exercises the generator to keep it in full functioning condition. By getting regular use, the generator's parts are more likely to move and function as needed.
Prevents wet stacking: A load bank test prevents wet stacking, which can happen when diesel-powered generators don't have regular use and soot builds in the system. A load bank test runs fuels through the generator, helping burn off the diesel inside the engine.
Verifies generator ability: The load bank test verifies that the generator will be able to create various levels of power to support necessary electrical equipment during an outage.. If not approved, the effect would be: Without adequate load testing, the facility wont be able to validate the correct operational performance of the back-up system during load.

input.project_name: UPM-2772246 - 9672 279 ST, Acheson (WLDC) - WLDC-Cooling Tower Bearing replacement
input.status_history: here is the status change history of project in numbering order(1):billing completed by Maureen Gerlach (2):work planning by Maureen Gerlach (3):offer approved by Maureen Gerlach (4):offer submitted by Maureen Gerlach

scope_of_work.notes:
1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process
scope_of_work.problem: We have been having issues with vibrations and vibration lock outs of our Cooling towers when running at 100 percent load. We had the vendor in assess the towers and ahs shown that the fan bearings need replacement on the cooling towers. There is significant play in the the bearings which is causing the vibration issues.
scope_of_work.scope: Vendor to supply and install upper and lower fan bearings on all 4 cooling towers at WLDC.
scope_of_work.justification: These towers are needed for critical cooling systems and we need the running at 100 percent. The bearings are not at complete failure but need replacement before any major issues arise.
scope_of_work.non_approval_effect: Possible major failure of critical cooling systems

output.overview: Project 'UPM-2773357 - 9672 279 ST, Acheson (WLDC) - WLDC-3 year dry sprinkler testing' in Canada at site Cole, Will and Effertz managed by Clarisync.com and prepared by Maureen Gerlach for client Kyndryl. Internal Work Order: CA-EW-05072022-3618, Status: Work Order Closed.
output.project_scope:
The scope notes highlight: 1. Does not include any client contingency 
2. Assumes that CBRE hold the burden of the actual cost whether it is over or under the quotation value 
3. Maintenance contract budget variations as a result of project activity will be funded by client through the eBVO process. The problem statement indicates: Our dry sprinkler zone on the fire safety system is due for 3 year testing. This is required to keep the system in proper working condition. The defined scope of work includes: Vendor to come to site and perform pressure testing on the dry sprinkler zone. The justification provided is: this is for fire life safety and needs to be working properly. If not approved, the effect would be: possible failure of fire life safety system.
